title: Senate Advances Bill to End 40-Day Government Shutdown
snippets: The Senate voted late Sunday evening on a compromise that could reopen the government following the longest shutdown in history.
Senate takes first step toward ending the government shutdown AP News
A group of Democrats voted with Republicans to advance a measure to end a 40-day shutdown, the longest in US history.
Trump offers more insight into proposal that directs subsidies directly to the American people to pay for health care rather than sending funds insurance companies.

Senators vote on advancing House-passed stopgap funding bill, suggesting end to historic 40-day shutdown in reach The US Senate on Sunday took a key vote on a bill that would end the record-setting federal government shutdown without extending the healthcare subsidies that Democrats have demanded. S
Aussie gains, yen weakens as end to US shutdown looks possible Reuters
US Senate advances bill to end federal shutdown Reuters
The measure signals a major breakthrough but the deal still needs to get over more hurdles in Congress.
Six Democratic Senators split with their party and voted to advance a package that would reopen the government.
titles: Senators take first step toward reopening the government after historic shutdown
Senate takes first step toward ending the government shutdown - AP News

Aussie gains, yen weakens as end to US shutdown looks possible - Reuters
US Senate advances bill to end federal shutdown - Reuters

summary: The US Senate voted late Sunday to advance a bill aimed at ending the record 40-day federal government shutdown, marking a significant step toward reopening the government. The compromise measure, which passed with support from both Democrats and Republicans, does not extend healthcare subsidies as previously demanded by Democrats. Six Democratic senators broke ranks to vote with Republicans. The bill still faces additional hurdles before becoming law. This development suggests a potential end to the longest government shutdown in US history.

title: Typhoon Fung-wong Hits Philippines: 4 Dead, 1.4M Displaced
snippets: Typhoon Fung-wong blew out of the Philippines after setting off floods and landslides, knocking out power to entire provinces, killing at least four people and displacing more than 1.4 million.

Less than a week after a storm left more than 200 people dead in the Philippines, an even stronger one hit.
Grabbing children and leaving their homes behind, residents evacuated before Typhoon Fung-wong hit.
Typhoon Fung-wong made landfall on the main island of Luzon, prompting the evacuation of more than one million people, just days after an earlier storm killed over 200.

Super Typhoon Fung-wong slammed ashore Sunday on the northeastern coast of the Philippines, where the massive storm had already left at least two people dead and forced more than a million people to evacuate from flood- and landslide-prone areas, officials said.
Super Typhoon Fung-wong slammed into the Philippines' eastern seaboard on Sunday, the national weather service said, after killing at least two people and forcing more than a million to evacuate.

summary: Typhoon Fung-wong, after hitting the Philippines, caused widespread destruction, triggering floods and landslides, and leading to power outages across provinces. The storm resulted in at least four fatalities and displaced over 1.4 million people. The typhoon, which made landfall on the northeastern coast of Luzon, weakened as it moved away from the Philippines.

title: BBC Leaders Resign Over Trump Speech Edit Controversy
snippets: BBC boss and head of news quit after criticism of Trump documentary edit Reuters
The director general and the UK broadcaster's top news executive quit in a row over the editing of a speech Donald Trump made before protesters attacked the US Capitol in Washington.

Exit comes after broadcaster accused of bias on US president, Gaza war and its coverage of rights of transgender people
The BBC has come under fire over a Panorama documentary that was accused of misleadingly editing a speech by Donald Trump.

summary: The BBC's director general and head of news resigned following criticism over the misleading editing of Donald Trump's speech in a documentary, ahead of the Capitol riot on January 6. The controversy, part of broader accusations of bias in the broadcaster's coverage, prompted their departure.

Eight Democrats joined Republicans in support of the deal, which lacks a guarantee for extended healthcare subsidies. The agreement, still requiring House approval and the President's signature, has prompted a positive reaction from markets, with US stock futures and Treasury yields rising in anticipation of the resolution.

title: Cleveland Pitchers Indicted in MLB Bribery Scandal
snippets: Two Major League Baseball pitchers have been indicted on charges they took bribes to give bettors advance notice of the types of pitches they'd throw and intentionally tossed balls instead of strikes.
MLB pitchers Emmanuel Clase and Luis Ortiz charged with taking bribes to rig pitches for bettors AP News
Each pitcher could face up to 65 years in prison if convicted on all charges

Cleveland Guardians pitchers Emmanuel Clase and Luis Ortiz have been charged with taking bribes from sports bettors to intentionally throw certain types of pitches, including tossing balls instead of strikes to ensure successful bets.
Ortiz, 26, was arrested by the FBI on Sunday at Boston Logan International Airport. He is expected to appear in federal court in Boston on Monday. Clase, 27, is not yet in custody.

NEW YORK (AP) — Cleveland Guardians pitchers Emmanuel Clase and Luis Ortiz have been indicted on charges they took bribes from sports bettors to throw certain types of pitches, including tossing balls in the dirt instead of strikes, to ensure successful bets. summary: Cleveland Guardians pitchers Emmanuel Clase and Luis Ortiz were indicted for taking bribes to influence MLB game outcomes by signaling pitch types to bettors and intentionally throwing balls. Both have been on paid leave since July amid an MLB investigation into suspicious betting patterns. Clase and Ortiz face charges including wire fraud conspiracy. Ortiz is currently in custody.

title: Basketball Legend Lenny Wilkens Dies at 88
snippets: Wilkens' family announced the news but did not divulge a cause of death of the Basketball Hall of Fame player and coach.
Wilkens brought his calm and savvy style as a point guard to the sideline.
Lenny Wilkens, a smooth playmaker who was inducted into the Basketball Hall of Fame as both a player and a coach, has died. He was 88.

Lenny Wilkens, a three-time inductee into the Basketball Hall of Fame who was enshrined as both a player and a coach, has died, his family said Sunday. He was 88. The family said Wilkens was surrounded by loved ones when he died and did not immediately release a cause of death.
Lenny Wilkens, Hall of Fame NBA Player and Coach, Dies at 88 Sports Illustrated

SEATTLE — Lenny Wilkens, a three-time inductee into the Basketball Hall of Fame who was enshrined as both a player and a coach, has died, his family said Sunday. He was 88. The family said Wilkens was surrounded by loved ones when he died and did not immediately release a cause of death. Wilkens was one of the finest point guards of his era who later brought his calm and savvy style to the sideline, first as a player-coach and then evolving into one of the game’s great coaches. He coached 2,487 games in the NBA, which is still a record. He became a Hall of Famer as a player, as a coach and...
Wilkens enjoyed one of the most decorated careers in basketball history
titles: Lenny Wilkens, legendary NBA player and coach, dies at 88

summary: Lenny Wilkens, a celebrated figure in basketball known for his distinguished career as both a player and a coach, has passed away at the age of 88. His family confirmed his death, stating he was surrounded by loved ones, but did not provide a cause of death. Wilkens was a three-time inductee into the Basketball Hall of Fame, recognized for his achievements on the court as a point guard and on the sidelines as a coach. He holds the record for coaching 2,487 NBA games.

title: Trump Admin Orders States to End Expanded SNAP Benefits Amid Shutdown
snippets: The Trump administration late Saturday directed states that they must "immediately undo" any actions they have made to provide full benefits to low-income families via SNAP.
Trump administration orders states to "undo" full SNAP benefits Axios
The Trump administration has resisted continuing the SNAP program, which provides food stamps to 42 million Americans, during the government shutdown.

U.S. President Donald Trump's administration is demanding states "undo" full SNAP food benefits paid out under judges' orders over the past week, now that the U.S. Supreme Court has stayed those rulings — marking the latest swing in a seesawing legal battle over the anti-hunger program used by 42 mi

States administering a federal food aid program serving about 42 million Americans faced uncertainty Monday over whether they can — and should — provide full monthly benefits during an ongoing legal battle involving the U.S. government shutdown.
Trump Administration Tells States to Undo Full Food-Aid Funding Bloomberg.com
In a filing in federal court on Sunday, the agency said states moved too quickly and erroneously released full money SNAP Benefits after last week's rulings.
Trump administration demands states 'undo' full SNAP payouts as states warn of 'catastrophic impact' AP News
titles: Trump admin order to 'immediately undo' full SNAP benefits leaves states scrambling
Trump administration orders states to "undo" full SNAP benefits - Axios
Trump administration demands that states 'undo' full SNAP benefit payments

summary: The Trump administration has ordered states to reverse actions that provided full SNAP (Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program) benefits to low-income families amid the government shutdown. This directive affects 42 million Americans dependent on food stamps. The decision, enforced through potential financial penalties for non-compliance, follows a Supreme Court stay on lower court rulings that had allowed the benefits. This move has sparked concerns over the potential catastrophic impact on those reliant on the program during the shutdown.

summary: New York Giants rookie quarterback Jaxson Dart was ruled out during the fourth quarter of a game against the Chicago Bears due to a concussion. This occurred after Dart was hit hard on a designed run in the third quarter. Following the injury, Giants coach Brian Daboll did not provide specific plans for the quarterback position moving forward. Additionally, the team's loss to the Bears has led to a backlash from fans, with some calling for Daboll's firing.

title: Israel Confirms Return of Soldier's Remains from Gaza After 11 Years

The Israeli military confirmed the soldier's body had been returned from Gaza after 11 years on Sunday.
Israel confirms receiving the remains of a soldier killed in Gaza in 2014 AP News
Body identified as Israeli soldier Hadar Goldin with the remains of four other deceased captives still in Gaza.
After conducting forensic tests, Israel has confirmed that the remains belong to Hadar Goldin, a soldier killed in Gaza during a humanitarian ceasefire in the 2014 war.

summary: Israel confirmed the return of Hadar Goldin's remains, a soldier killed in Gaza during a 2014 ceasefire, after 11 years. The Israeli military received his body from Gaza, with the remains of four other captives still held. Forensic tests verified the identity of the remains as Goldin's.

title: South Korea's Ex-President Yoon Indicted for Allegedly Provoking North Korea
snippets: South Korea special prosecutor indicts ex-President Yoon on more charges Reuters
Yoon Suk Yeol ordered drone flights over North Korea to create pretext for martial law, prosecutors allege.
A special prosecutor accused Yoon Suk Yeol, South Korea's ousted president, of trying to stoke tensions by ordering drones into North Korea.
Special prosecutors accused ex-president Yoon Suk Yeol of attempting to goad North Korea into conflict as a pretext for declaring martial law in December 2024.

summary: A special prosecutor in South Korea has indicted former President Yoon Suk Yeol on charges of attempting to provoke North Korea by ordering drone flights over its territory. These actions were allegedly aimed at creating a pretext for declaring martial law. This development marks a significant escalation in the legal challenges facing Yoon, who has been accused of trying to stoke tensions with North Korea for political purposes.

title: Brindley's OT Goal Lifts Avalanche Over Canucks 5-4; MacKinnon Shines

Nathan MacKinnon starred with two goals and three assists, playing a crucial role in the win by assisting Brindley's game-winning goal. This match marked Brindley's first career overtime winner.

This statement comes as the Supreme Court reviews challenges to the policy. Trump suggested on Truth Social that the payment could be distributed in various forms, potentially through tax cuts, according to Bloomberg. The final method of distribution remains unspecified.

title: Norris Wins Brazilian GP, Extends Lead in F1 Championship

McLaren driver Lando Norris significantly extended his lead in the F1 championship after winning the Brazilian Grand Prix on Sunday, with his main rival and teammate Oscar Piastri receiving a 10-second penalty and again failing to make the podium.
Lando Norris extended his championship lead with a victory in Sao Paulo, while Max Verstappen completed a masterful comeback from the pit lane to finish in third.

With three races left, Norris strengthens his position in the championship standings.

title: Indonesia Awards Ex-President Suharto National Hero Status Amid Criticism
snippets: Indonesia grants national hero status to late strongman President Suharto Reuters

Former leader presided over period marked by corruption, nepotism, censorship and claims of rights abuses Indonesia has awarded former authoritarian leader Suharto the title of national hero, in a move that has sparked accusations of historical revisionism in the world’s third-largest democracy. The
titles: Indonesia grants national hero status to late strongman President Suharto - Reuters

summary: Indonesia has posthumously awarded former President Suharto national hero status, a decision made by his ex-son-in-law, President Prabowo. This move has faced criticism from activists who see it as a betrayal of Suharto's victims and an affront to democracy, given Suharto's tenure was marred by corruption, nepotism, censorship, and human rights abuses. Critics accuse the government of historical revisionism.

summary: Air travel in the U.S. is facing significant disruption, with over 2,500 flights already canceled. The Transportation Secretary warned that flight reductions could reach 20% if the current shutdown continues into next week. Airlines may cut hundreds more flights, potentially slowing air travel to a "trickle" before Thanksgiving, as reported by Axios and observed at major airports nationwide.

title: Chara, Keith, Thornton Among 2023 Hockey Hall of Fame Inductees
snippets: Matthews salutes Thornton after Hockey Hall of Fame induction NHL.com

Zdeno Chara and Duncan Keith will be inducted into the Hall of Fame alongside fellow former players Joe Thornton, Alexander Mogilny, Jennifer Botterill and Brianna Decker on Monday in Toronto. Jack Parker and Danièle Sauvageau will enter as builders.

Zdeno Chara could hardly believe what had just unfolded. Duncan Keith was in the same boat — at the opposite end of the emotional spectrum. Chara and his Boston Bruins held a 2-1 lead late in Game 6 of the 2013 Stanley Cup final against Keith and the Chicago Blackhawks. A victory on home ice would ensure a winner-take-all finale back in the Windy City. That script then flipped in dramatic fashion. The visitors scored twice in a jaw-dropping 17-second span to stun the Bruins 3-2 and claim the Blackhawks’ second Cup in four years. “Shocking for us,” Chara recalled more than a decade later....
titles: Matthews salutes Thornton after Hockey Hall of Fame induction - NHL.com
Chara, Keith, Thornton and rest of Hockey Hall of Fame's 2025 class set for Monday induction
‘Very fortunate’: Hockey Hall of Fame’s 2025 class set for induction
summary: Zdeno Chara, Duncan Keith, Joe Thornton, Alexander Mogilny, Jennifer Botterill, and Brianna Decker were inducted into the Hockey Hall of Fame, with Jack Parker and Danièle Sauvageau entering as builders. The ceremony took place in Toronto. The news recalls a dramatic moment from the 2013 Stanley Cup final where Chara's Bruins lost to Keith's Blackhawks after Chicago scored twice in 17 seconds to win the Cup.

title: Maple Leafs Coach Berube Critiques Team's Defense After Hurricanes Game
snippets: Craig Berube has a front-row seat to what is quickly becoming a horror show.

Toronto Maple Leafs head coach Craig Berube sounds off on the team’s defensive effort against the Hurricanes, stating the roster doesn’t have the proper mindset at the moment and details the need to value the defensive side of the puck more.
titles: Berube blasts Maple Leafs’ defensive commitment
‘We didn’t check anyone’: Berube sounds off on Maple Leafs defence
summary: Toronto Maple Leafs head coach Craig Berube criticized the team's defensive effort following a game against the Hurricanes. He highlighted a lack of proper mindset within the roster and emphasized the need to prioritize defense.

title: Disney Channels, Including ESPN, Go Dark on YouTube TV Amid Dispute
snippets: Disney and YouTube TV's parent company, Google, have yet to agree on a new licensing contract, leaving YouTube TV subscribers in a bind.
YouTube TV subscribers unhappy about going more than a week without ESPN, ABC, and other Disney networks will be getting a $20 credit that can be applied to their next billing statement.

On October 31st, ESPN, ABC, Nat Geo, and over 20 other Disney-owned channels went dark on YouTube TV. As the two sides disagree about terms for a new content distribution contract, Google has accused Disney of trying to raise prices for its customers in an effort to boost its own Hulu + Live TV and
titles: YouTube TV is now offering customers a $20 credit as its conflict with Disney drags on
YouTube TV is giving customers a $20 credit for Disney blackout
YouTube TV, ESPN, and Disney: the latest on the blackout
summary: Disney and Google have not reached a new licensing agreement, causing over 20 Disney-owned channels, including ESPN and ABC, to go dark on YouTube TV since October 31st. As negotiations continue, with Google accusing Disney of attempting to raise prices, YouTube TV is offering subscribers a $20 credit for the inconvenience.

title: Syrian President al-Sharaa to Meet Trump at White House, First Since 1946
snippets: Ahmed al-Sharaa is expected to push for full lifting of remaining sanctions imposed during 13-year civil war Syria’s president, Ahmed al-Sharaa , will on Monday hold talks with Donald Trump at the White House, the first such official visit by a Syrian leader since national independence in 1946. He i
Ahmed al-Sharaa, the rebel leader who became Syria’s president after ousting Bashar al-Assad, has walked an improbable path from al-Qaeda to the West Wing.
titles: Syrian president to hold talks with Trump at White House
Syrian president to meet with Trump in White House after unlikely ascent
summary: Ahmed al-Sharaa, Syria's president and former rebel leader, will meet with Donald Trump at the White House on Monday, marking the first official visit by a Syrian leader since 1946. Al-Sharaa, who rose to power after ousting Bashar al-Assad and has a history with al-Qaeda, aims to discuss the full lifting of sanctions imposed during Syria's 13-year civil war.

title: U.S. Airlines Cancel 2,700+ Flights Amid Shutdown, Affecting Thanksgiving Travel
snippets: US airlines’ daily cancellations exceed 2,700 as shutdown impact extends AP News

WASHINGTON (AP) — U.S. airlines canceled more than 2,100 flights on Sunday as Transportation Secretary Sean Duffy warned that air traffic in the U.S. could “slow to a trickle” if the federal government shutdown lingers into the busy Thanksgiving travel holiday season. The slowdown at 40 of the natio
titles: US airlines’ daily cancellations exceed 2,700 as shutdown impact extends - AP News
US airlines’ daily cancellations top 2,000 for first time since shutdown cuts began
summary: U.S. airlines canceled over 2,100 flights on Sunday, with the total exceeding 2,700 due to the federal government shutdown. Transportation Secretary Sean Duffy warned that air traffic could significantly slow, impacting the Thanksgiving travel season. The disruption affects 40 national airports.

title: Super-Typhoon in Philippines: 2 Dead, 1.4M Displaced
snippets: Powerful storm set off floods and landslides, killing at least two and displacing 1.4 million .

At least two people found dead as super-typhoon hits Philippines, days after Typhoon Kalmaegi killed at least 224 More than 1 million people have been evacuated from their homes in the Philippines and at least two people have been killed as Typhoon Fung-wong – the second big storm to hit in days – m
titles: Philippines assesses damage after deadly Typhoon Fung-wong
More than 1 million evacuated in the Philippines as Typhoon Fung-wong makes landfall
summary: A super-typhoon in the Philippines resulted in at least two deaths and displaced over 1.4 million people. This follows Typhoon Kalmaegi, which claimed at least 224 lives. Typhoon Fung-wong, marking the second major storm in a short period, caused widespread evacuations and significant damage.

title: Hamas Returns Remains of Lt. Hadar Goldin to Israel from 2014 Gaza War
snippets: Here’s what to know about hostages and others whose bodies have been returned by Hamas to Israel, and those who remain in Gaza.
Hamas returned to Israel the remains of Lt. Hadar Goldin, who was killed in a 2014 war in Gaza.
titles: Body of Israeli soldier Hadar Goldin returned from Gaza after 11 years
Hamas Hands Over Body of Hadar Goldin, Israeli Soldier Held Since 2014
summary: Hamas has returned the remains of Lt. Hadar Goldin to Israel. Goldin was killed in the 2014 Gaza war. This development is part of the ongoing issue of hostages and remains of individuals between Israel and Hamas, with some still remaining in Gaza.

title: Blue Origin Delays New Glenn Rocket Launch Due to Weather
snippets: Jeff Bezos’ Blue Origin Rocket Set to Launch First NASA Mission Bloomberg.com
Blue Origin, the space company owned by billionaire Jeff Bezos, was forced Sunday to postpone the anticipated launch of its New Glenn rocket due to unfavorable weather conditions.
New Glenn, the towering rocket built by Jeff Bezos's space company Blue Origin, is set to take off on its second mission Sunday as competition intensifies with Elon Musk's SpaceX.
titles: Jeff Bezos’ Blue Origin Rocket Set to Launch First NASA Mission - Bloomberg.com
Bezos's Blue Origin postpones rocket launch over weather
Bezos's Blue Origin set to launch NASA mission to Mars
summary: Blue Origin, owned by Jeff Bezos, postponed the launch of its New Glenn rocket, initially planned for its first NASA mission, due to bad weather. This event marks a significant step for Blue Origin as it competes with Elon Musk's SpaceX.
